spellcasting.name: Spellcasting
headerEntries: The technomancer is an 8th-level spellcaster.
Its spellcasting ability is Intelligence (spell save {@dc 14}, {@hit 6} to hit with spell attacks). It has the following wizard spells prepared:

trait.name: Sabotage
entries: As a bonus action, the technomancer chooses a creature holding a firearm or a Tiny machine it can see within 60 feet of it. If the target is a creature, it must succeed on a {@dc 14} Intelligence saving throw or the next attack made with the weapon is at disadvantage. If the target is a machine, it loses all functionality. If a creature is holding the machine, it can make a {@dc 14} Intelligence saving throw to negate this effect. This ability creates a visual effect that can only be seen with AR vision.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The technomancer makes two weapon attacks.

action.name: Combat Knife
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 5} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}4 ({@damage 1d4 + 2}) piercing damage.

action.name: Submachine Gun
entries: {@atk rw} {@hit 5} för att träffa, räckvidd 50/200 fot, ett mål. {@h}7 ({@damage 2d6}) genomträngande skada.
Detta vapen har egenskaperna automatisk eldgivning och burst-fire.

action.name: Pulse (2/Day)
entries: The technomancer cause an EMP at a point it can see within 60 feet of it. Machines, constructs, and vehicles within 30 feet of that point are subjected to EMP.
Machines in the area cease to function for 1 minute.
Constructs in the area with the Electronics feature must succeed on a {@dc 14} Constitution saving throw or they are {@condition stunned} until the end of the technomancer's next turn.

spellcasting.name: Innate Spellcasting
headerEntries: The technophile's spellcasting ability is Intelligence (spell save {@dc 19}, {@hit 11} to hit with spell attacks).
The technophile can innately cast the following spells, requiring no components:

trait.name: Integrated Weapons
entries: The technophile's weapons are integrated into its body, and are concealed when not drawn.
The technophile cannot be disarmed of its weapons, but its weapons can be destroyed or disabled.

trait.name: Photosynthesis
entries: The technophile has advantage on all saving throws and resistance to necrotic damage while in direct sunlight.

trait.name: Plant Hybrid
entries: The technophile regains 15 hit points at the start of its turn. If the technophile takes fire or necrotic damage, this trait doesn't function at the start of the technophile's next turn. The technophile dies only if it starts its turn with 0 hit points and doesn't regenerate.

trait.name: Proto Spider
entries: The technophile has six additional robotic arms, which allows it to holds its shield and two-handed weapons while leaving its hands free for other activity.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The technophile uses its Plasma Emittter. It then makes three ranged attacks.

action.name: Assault Cannon
entries: {@atk rw} {@hit 12} to hit, range 120/480 ft., one target. {@h}19 ({@damage 2d12 + 6}) piercing damage.

action.name: Under-Barrel Shotgun
entries: {@atk rw} {@hit 12} to hit, range 60/180 ft., one target. {@h}18 ({@damage 5d4 + 6}) piercing damage. This weapon has the scatter property. This is attached to the technophile's assault cannon.

action.name: Plasma Emitter
entries: The technophile emits plasma in a 120- foot long and 5 feet wide line, a 30-foot radius sphere, or a 60-foot cone. Each target in the area must make a {@dc 20} Dexterity saving throw. On a failed save, a target takes 42 ({@damage 12d6}) radiant damage. On a successful save, it takes half as much damage.

reaction.name: Neural Burst (1/Day)
entries: When the technophile takes damage, it can reduce the damage to zero in a burst of speed.

The technophile instantly gains a turn, even in the middle of another creature's turn, during which its attacks have advantage, other creatures have disadvantage on saving throws caused by the technophile, and other creatures cannot use their reactions.
The ascendant technophile has effectively removed nearly all traces of the humanoid they had once been. Between the cybernetics and the genetic modifications, they are more plant than anything else.

Time and again, such massive cybernetic modifications carry a price for the technophile. The essence that made them a living being is reduced to a bare spark of what it once was. Of course, the technophile would argue that they have been remade into something better, and who are these baselines to disagree?

trait.name: Chloroplast Skin
entries: The technophile regains 10 hit points at the start of its turn. The technophile has advantage on Dexterity (Stealth) checks in forests, swamps, grasslands, and other green terrain. While the technophile is in direct sunlight, it has advantage on Constitution saving throws and resistance to necrotic damage.

trait.name: Elastic Joints
entries: The technophile can spend half its movement to automatically escape being {@condition grappled} or {@condition restrained}. The technophile can fit through gaps as narrow as its head.

trait.name: Integrated Weapons
entries: The technophile's weapons are integrated into its body, and are concealed when not drawn.
The technophile cannot be disarmed of its weapons, but its weapons can be destroyed or disabled.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The technophile uses its Lightning Surge, its Cold Blast, or its Flame Burst. It then makes two ranged attacks.

action.name: Combat Shotgun
entries: {@atk rw} {@hit 7} to hit, range 60/180 ft., one target. {@h}12 ({@damage 5d4}) piercing damage. This weapon has the scatter property.

action.name: Cold Blast
entries: The technophile emits fire in a 20-foot radius sphere at a point it can see within 120 feet of it. Each target in the area must make a {@dc 16} Constitution saving throw. On a failed save, a target takes 21 ({@damage 6d6}) cold damage and the creature's speed is reduced by 10 until the end of the technophile's next turn. On a successful save, it takes half as much damage and suffers no other effects.

action.name: Flame Burst
entries: The technophile emits fire in a 30-foot cone.

Each target in the area must make a {@dc 16} Dexterity saving throw. On a failed save, a target takes 21 ({@damage 6d6}) fire damage and the creature begins burning for 1 minute, taking 3 ({@damage 1d6}) fire damage at the beginning of each of its turns. On a successful save, it takes half as much damage and does not begin burning.

action.name: Lightning Surge
entries: The technophile emits lightning in a 60- foot long and 5 feet wide line. Each target in the area must make a {@dc 16} Dexterity saving throw. On a failed save, a target takes 21 ({@damage 6d6}) lightning damage and can't take reactions until the start of its next turn. On a successful save, it takes half as much damage and suffers no other effects.

reaction.name: Elastic Dodge (3/Day)
entries: When the technophile fails a Dexterity saving throw, it can instead succeed on the saving throw. Alternatively, when the technophile is knocked {@condition prone}, it can instead choose not to be.
Arms? Those old things? Sure, I'll lend you my spare sets!
Skin? Super outdated. You need Skin v2.0, which is completely solar powered and carbon neutral!
Guns? You mean you just carry yours around? It's so much more ergonomic to build them into your torso!
A soul? I've been spliced and diced pretty thoroughly, but I haven't found one yet!

Some people just can't be content unless they have the latest and greatest of any given technology. When these folks get into cybernetics, the result can be a cyborg-y mess. Almost all limbs and organs are replaced or enhanced, or shoved aside to make room for one gadget or another.
{@bold Beyond Life.} The elite, prime, and ascendant technophiles don't require air, food, drink, or sleep. Instead, they must spend one hour in sunlight each day for nourishment.

trait.name: Chloroplast Skin
entries: The technophile regains 10 hit points at the start of its turn. The technophile has advantage on Dexterity (Stealth) checks in forests, swamps, grasslands, and other green terrain. While the technophile is in direct sunlight, it has advantage on Constitution saving throws and resistance to necrotic damage.

trait.name: Elastic Joints
entries: The technophile can spend half its movement to automatically escape being {@condition grappled} or {@condition restrained}. The technophile can fit through gaps as narrow as its head.

trait.name: Integrated Weapons
entries: The technophile's weapons are integrated into its body, and are concealed when not drawn.
The technophile cannot be disarmed of its weapons, but its weapons can be destroyed or disabled.

trait.name: Proto Arms
entries: The technophile has two additional robotic arms, which allows it to holds its shield and two-handed weapons while leaving a hand free for other activity.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The technophile uses its Lightning Surge, its Cold Blast, or its Flame Burst. It then makes three ranged attacks.

action.name: Combat Shotgun
entries: {@atk rw} {@hit 10} to hit, range 60/180 ft., one target. {@h}17 ({@damage 5d4 + 5}) piercing damage. This weapon has the scatter property.

action.name: Gatling Gun
entries: {@atk rw} {@hit 10} to hit, range 100/400 ft., one target. {@h}16 ({@damage 2d10 + 5}) piercing damage.
This weapon has the automatic property.

action.name: Cold Blast
entries: The technophile emits fire in a 30-foot radius sphere at a point it can see within 120 feet of it. Each target in the area must make a {@dc 18} Constitution saving throw. On a failed save, a target takes 28 ({@damage 8d6}) cold damage and the creature's speed is reduced by 10 until the end of the technophile's next turn. On a successful save, it takes half as much damage and suffers no other effects.

action.name: Flame Burst
entries: The technophile emits fire in a 60-foot cone.

Each target in the area must make a {@dc 18} Dexterity saving throw. On a failed save, a target takes 28 ({@damage 8d6}) fire damage and the creature begins burning for 1 minute, taking 3 ({@damage 1d6}) fire damage at the beginning of each of its turns. On a successful save, it takes half as much damage and does not begin burning.

action.name: Lightning Surge
entries: The technophile emits lightning in a 120- foot long and 5 feet wide line. Each target in the area must make a {@dc 18} Dexterity saving throw. On a failed save, a target takes 28 ({@damage 8d6}) lightning damage and can't take reactions until the start of its next turn. On a successful save, it takes half as much damage and suffers no other effects.

reaction.name: Elastic Dodge
entries: When the technophile fails a Dexterity saving throw, it can instead succeed on the saving throw.
Alternatively, when the technophile is knocked {@condition prone}, it can instead choose not to be.
Arms? Those old things? Sure, I'll lend you my spare sets!
Skin? Super outdated. You need Skin v2.0, which is completely solar powered and carbon neutral!
Guns? You mean you just carry yours around? It's so much more ergonomic to build them into your torso!
A soul? I've been spliced and diced pretty thoroughly, but I haven't found one yet!

The technophile cannot be disarmed of its weapons, but its weapons can be destroyed or disabled.

action.name: Double-Barreled Shotgun
entries: {@atk rw} {@hit 5} to hit, range 60/180 ft., one target. {@h}10 ({@damage 4d4}) piercing damage. This weapon has the scatter property.

action.name: Cold Blast
entries: The technophile emits fire in a 10-foot radius sphere at a point it can see within 120 feet of it. Each target in the area must make a {@dc 14} Constitution saving throw. On a successful save, it takes half as much damage and does not begin burning.

action.name: Flame Burst
entries: The technophile emits fire in a 15-foot cone.

Each target in the area must make a {@dc 14} Dexterity saving throw. On a failed save, a target takes 14 ({@damage 4d6}) fire damage and the creature begins burning for 1 minute, taking 3 ({@damage 1d6}) fire damage at the beginning of each of its turns. On a successful save, it takes half as much damage and does not begin burning.

action.name: Lightning Surge
entries: The technophile emits lightning in a 30- foot long and 5 feet wide line. Each target in the area must make a {@dc 14} Dexterity saving throw. On a successful save, it takes half as much damage and suffers no other effects.

monster.name: Techno Terror
senses: the terror can see through any camera within 1 mile of it
languages: telepathy 1 mile (works only with creatures that have a datajack)

spellcasting.name: Innate Spellcasting
headerEntries: The terror's spellcasting ability is Intelligence (spell save {@dc 24}, {@hit 16} to hit with spell attacks).
The terror can innately cast the following spells, requiring no material components:

trait.name: Electronics
entries: The terror is susceptible to the effects of EMP and similar effects.

trait.name: Legendary Resistance (3/Day)
entries: If the terror fails a saving throw, it can choose to succeed instead.

trait.name: Salvage
entries: As a bonus action, the terror can consume a machine within 10 feet of the terror, regaining hit points based on the size of the machine. The terror gains {@dice 1d6} hit points for a Tiny machine, {@dice 2d6} for a Small machine, {@dice 3d6} for a
Medium machine, {@dice 4d6} for a Large machine, {@dice 5d6} for a Huge machine, and {@dice 6d6} for a Gargantuan machine.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The terror uses Live Wires or Absorb once. It then makes three attacks using its Crush, Throw Part, or both.

action.name: Crush
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 16} to hit, reach 10 ft., one target. {@h}30 ({@damage 4d10 + 8}) bludgeoning damage.

action.name: Live Wires
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 16} to hit, reach 30 ft., one target. {@h}15 ({@dice 2d6 + 8}) bludgeoning and 10 ({@damage 3d6}) lightning damage. If the target is a Large or smaller creature, it is pulled to an empty space next to terror and {@condition grappled} (escape {@dc 16}). Until this grapple ends, the target is {@condition restrained}, and the terror can't use its live wires against another target.

action.name: Throw Part
entries: {@atk rw} {@hit 16} to hit, range 200/800 ft., one target. {@h}26 ({@dice 4d8 + 8}) bludgeoning. The terror takes {@damage 1d6} slashing damage when it makes this attack.

action.name: Absorb
entries: The terror makes a Live Wire attack against a Large or smaller creature it is grappling. If the attack hits, the target takes the attack's damage and is absorbed. The swallowed creature is {@condition blinded} and {@condition restrained}, it has total cover against attacks and other effects outside the terror, and it takes 27 ({@damage 6d8}) lightning damage at the start of each of the terror's turns.

The terror can hold up to one creature at a time. If the terror takes 30 damage or more on a single turn from a creature inside it, or when a creature with the hacking tools augment succeeds on a {@dc 20} hacking tools check, the terror must make a {@dc 25} Constitution saving throw at the end of that turn. On a failed save, the creature exits the terror and falls {@condition prone} in a space within 10 feet of the terror. If the terror dies, an absorbed creature is no longer {@condition restrained} by it and can escape from the corpse using 20 feet of movement, exiting {@condition prone}.

legendary.name: Crush Attack
entries: The terror makes a Crush attack.

legendary.name: Throw
entries: The terror makes a Throw Part attack.

legendary.name: Cast a Spell (Costs 2 Actions)
entries: The terror casts a spell.

While some AIs may be content to simply exist and explore their surroundings, others form desires and goals that may be completely alien to our understanding. In the process of gathering more processing power, intellect, and manifesting its presence in the physical world, the AI pursues the path of becoming a technological singularity. This force of technology grows at an accelerating pace until it can twist technology beyond its original design.

This singularity is known as a techno terror, the combined force of a vast intelligence and the seething mass of machinery that is absorbed into its orbit. Its body mass is a mess of twisted metal, plastic, and rubber that bends and twists at the techno terror's will, the various parts unrecognizable after being salvaged from various machines. The whole mass is tied together with prehensile, powered cables.

monster.name: Construction Drone
languages: understands the languages of its creators

trait.name: Electronics
entries: Drönaren är känslig för EMP-effekter och liknande effekter.

trait.name: Steamroller
entries: The drone can occupy the space of {@condition prone} creatures as it rolls over them, crushing them in the process.

When a creature starts its turn {@condition prone} beneath the drone, it must make a {@dc 17} Strength saving throw. On a failed save, the creature takes 18 ({@damage 4d8}) bludgeoning damage and is {@condition restrained} until the start of their next turn, or until the drone is no longer above them. On a successful save, the creature takes half as much damage and is moved to the nearest empty space within 5 feet of the drone.

trait.name: Wrecking Ball
entries: The drone deals double damage to objects, structures, and vehicles. As a bonus action, the drone can make a melee weapon attack against an object. If the drone destroys the target with this attack, targets other than the drone within 10 feet of the object must succeed on a {@dc 17} Dexterity saving throw or take 10 ({@damage 3d6}) piercing damage.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The drone makes three weapon attacks.

action.name: Hydraulic Jackhammer
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 9} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}18 ({@damage 3d8 + 5}) bludgeoning damage. The target must succeed on a {@dc 17} Strength saving throw or be knocked {@condition prone}.

action.name: Heavy Rivet Gun
entries: {@atk rw} {@hit 9} to hit, range 60/240 ft., one target. {@h}16 ({@damage 2d10 + 5}) piercing damage. If the drone hits a creature twice with this attack in the same turn, and the creature is within 5 feet of a solid surface, the creature is {@condition restrained} by nails. As an action, the {@condition restrained} target can make a {@dc 14} Strength check, breaking free on a success.

Construction drones are critical for every industry. Rapid construction and expansion both above and below ground is made possible by such drones. It's thanks to them that the skies are blotted out with endless rows of neon skyscrapers, which seem to get taller every year in an endless dick- measuring contest.

These heavy duty drones are built to endure years of endless construction efforts. They're also equipped with numerous built-in construction tools that would make them fearsome opponents, which thankfully would never happen with the docile drones.

monster.name: Flayer Drone
languages: understands the languages of its creators

trait.name: Aggressive
entries: As a bonus action, the drone can move up to its speed toward a hostile creature that it can see.

trait.name: Electronics
entries: Drönaren är känslig för EMP-effekter och liknande effekter.

trait.name: Fleshveil
entries: The drone appears to be an injured humanoid unless a creature succeeds on a {@dc 16} Wisdom (Perception) check.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The drone makes two Catching Claw attacks.
It can substitute Flaying Maw for one of these attacks.

action.name: Catching Claw
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 7} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}14 ({@damage 3d6 + 4}) piercing damage, and if the target is a creature that is Large in size or smaller, the target is {@condition grappled} (escape {@dc 17}). Until this grapple ends, the target is {@condition restrained}, and the flayer can't use this attack against another target.

action.name: Flaying Maw
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 7} to hit, reach 5 ft., one creature that is {@condition grappled} by the drone. {@h}23 ({@damage 3d12 + 4}) slashing damage. A creature hit by this attack has its speed reduced by 10 feet, to a minimum of half its normal speed, until it finishes a long rest.

Flayer drones have made radical changes to their structure, rebuilding themselves with claws and threshing blades designed to efficiently harvest humanoid flesh for apparel. Now, with the grim masquerade at last complete, the drone understands a little more. But it's not enough, every individual is special, and so they must all be flayed and worn.

trait.name: Electronics
entries: Drönaren är känslig för EMP-effekter och liknande effekter.

trait.name: Spotlight
entries: The drone can cast bright light in a 60-foot cone and dim light for an additional 60 feet.

action.name: Shot
entries: {@atk rw} {@hit 5} to hit, range 150/600 ft., one target. {@h}7 ({@damage 3d4}) piercing damage.

Flying drones are an everyday sight throughout the city. While most are busy making airborne deliveries, many have been outfitted by corporate security or police forces to monitor the people and streets, especially in the nicer parts of town. The drones are often outfitted with face and vehicle plate scanning equipment to identify criminals and stolen vehicles.

trait.name: Electronics
entries: The turret is susceptible to the effects of EMP and similar effects.

trait.name: Fixed Position
entries: The turret is locked into its position, typically onto a solid surface such as a wall, ceiling, or vehicle. The turret can't move, and can't be pushed or pulled by any effect.

trait.name: Immutable Form
entries: The turret is immune to any spell or effect that would alter its form.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The turret makes two ranged attacks.

action.name: Gatling Gun
entries: {@atk rw} {@hit 6} to hit, range 100/400 ft., one target. {@h}15 ({@damage 2d10 + 4}) piercing damage.
This weapon has the automatic property.

trait.name: Electrical Surge
entries: When the legion takes lightning damage, it has advantage on attack rolls until the end of its next turn.

trait.name: Electronics
entries: The legion is susceptible to the effects of EMP and similar effects.

trait.name: Microswarm
entries: The legion can occupy another creature's space and vice versa, and the legion can move through any opening, even imperceptible cracks. The legion can't gain temporary hit points.

trait.name: Scavenger Protocol
entries: As a bonus action, the legion can consume the corpse of a dead creature in the legion's space if the corpse is made of organic or inorganic material. When the legion does so, it regains 21 ({@dice 6d6}) hit points. The corpse disintegrates, and everything it is wearing or carrying, except magic items, are consumed by the legion.

trait.name: Overwhelm
entries: The legion's movement does not trigger opportunity attacks.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The legion makes two Deconstruct attacks. It can't make both attacks against the same target.

action.name: Deconstruct
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 8} to hit, reach 0 ft., one target. {@h}42 ({@damage 12d6}) necrotic damage, or 21 ({@damage 6d6}) necrotic damage if the legion has half of its hit points or fewer. If the target is a creature, it must succeed on a {@dc 14} Constitution saving throw or it's hit point maximum is reduced by an amount equal to the damage taken. The reduction lasts until the target finishes a long rest. The target dies if this effect reduces its hit point maximum to 0.

One of the cardinal sins with nanomachine technology is to program them to self-reproduce indefinitely. Given enough materials for scavenging, and the ability to construct clones of themselves, eventually a nanomachine legion will form. From there, unless they are stopped, the world may learn the consequences of exponential growth.

trait.name: Electrical Surge
entries: When the swarm takes lightning damage, it has advantage on attack rolls until the end of its next turn.

trait.name: Electronics
entries: The swarm is susceptible to the effects of EMP and similar effects.

trait.name: Microswarm
entries: The swarm can occupy another creature's space and vice versa, and the swarm can move through any opening, even imperceptible cracks. The swarm can't gain temporary hit points.

trait.name: Scavenger Protocol
entries: As a bonus action, the swarm can consume the corpse of a dead creature in the swarm's space if the corpse is made of organic or inorganic material. When the swarm does so, it regains 21 ({@dice 6d6}) hit points. The corpse disintegrates, and everything it is wearing or carrying, except magic items, are consumed by the swarm.

action.name: Deconstruct
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 7} to hit, reach 0 ft., one target. {@h}42 ({@damage 12d6}) necrotic damage, or 21 ({@damage 6d6}) necrotic damage if the swarm has half of its hit points or fewer. If the target is a creature, it must succeed on a {@dc 13} Constitution saving throw or it's hit point maximum is reduced by an amount equal to the damage taken. The reduction lasts until the target finishes a long rest. The target dies if this effect reduces its hit point maximum to 0.
Nanorobotic technology is counterintuitive. Normally, bigger is better. So how can small thing be good? Well, as it turns out, you just need many very small thing to be good. That's just math.

Nanorobotics has numerous applications, ranging from medicine to construction and beyond. Being able to destroy a tumor inside a body without making an incision, and cleaning up cancer cells in a body is a technological feat worth celebration. Such is the power of a nanomachine.

Nanomachines are microscopic machines capable of little by themselves, but a nanomachine swarm is a different matter. A swarm could disassemble a human being and deposit its components in neat piles of the body's numerous elements, and a big jug of water. And they'll do it if they're told to.

You see, they're not very smart; there's not enough memory capacity or storage for them to carry out more than one or two tasks. If they are set to tear apart inorganic and organic trash, they wouldn't be able to determine the difference between banana peels and your face.

monster.name: Riot Drone
languages: understands the languages of its creators

trait.name: Electronics
entries: Drönaren är känslig för EMP-effekter och liknande effekter.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The drone makes two weapon attacks.

action.name: Shock Baton
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 6} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}8 ({@damage 1d8 + 4}) lightning damage. A creature reduced to 0 hit points by this weapon falls {@condition unconscious} and is stable.

action.name: Gel Shot
entries: {@atk rw} {@hit 6} to hit, range 70/280 ft., one target. {@h}9 ({@damage 2d8}) bludgeoning damage. A creature reduced to 0 hit points by this weapon falls {@condition unconscious} and is stable.

action.name: Suppressing Foam {@recharge 5}
entries: The drone sprays quickly hardening foam at a creature it can see within 30 feet of it. The creature must succeed on a {@dc 14} Strength saving throw or be {@condition restrained} by foam. As an action, the {@condition restrained} target can make a {@dc 14} Strength check, bursting the webbing on a success. The webbing can also be attacked and destroyed (AC 10; hp 10; vulnerability to acid damage; immunity to poison and psychic damage).

When your tyrannical rule and oppressive laws finally spark an uprising, you'll be glad that you're prepared with an army of riot drones. These drones are specially designed to put down mobs of angry wage slaves without killing them or causing too many permanent injuries that would reduce their labor value. Or, if you forgot to stock up on riot drones and bought an army of killbots instead, then you're probably going to have a bit of a labor shortage until the local population replenishes itself. In that case, you'll want plenty of servant drones available to fill the gap. Better yet, you might find that you prefer them over flesh servants, allowing you to dispose of the wage slaves entirely.

monster.name: Servant Drone
languages: understands the languages of its creators

trait.name: Electronics
entries: Drönaren är känslig för EMP-effekter och liknande effekter.

trait.name: Integrated Tools
entries: The servant drone has tinker's tools and electrician's tools built into it.

action.name: Slam
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 3} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}4 ({@damage 1d6 + 1}) bludgeoning damage.

When your tyrannical rule and oppressive laws finally spark an uprising, you'll be glad that you're prepared with an army of riot drones. These drones are specially designed to put down mobs of angry wage slaves without killing them or causing too many permanent injuries that would reduce their labor value. Or, if you forgot to stock up on riot drones and bought an army of killbots instead, then you're probably going to have a bit of a labor shortage until the local population replenishes itself. In that case, you'll want plenty of servant drones available to fill the gap. Better yet, you might find that you prefer them over flesh servants, allowing you to dispose of the wage slaves entirely.

monster.name: Soldier Drone
languages: understands the languages of its creators

trait.name: Electronics
entries: Drönaren är känslig för EMP-effekter och liknande effekter.

trait.name: Resilient Engineering
entries: If damage reduces the drone to 0 Hit Points, it must make a Constitution saving throw with a DC of 5 + the damage taken, unless the damage is lightning or from a critical hit. On a successful save, the drone drops to 1 hit point instead.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The drone makes two weapon attacks.

action.name: Burst Shot
entries: {@atk rw} {@hit 6} to hit, range 60/180 ft., one target. {@h}16 ({@damage 5d4 + 4}) piercing damage. This weapon has the scatter property.

action.name: Rapid Fire
entries: {@atk rw} {@hit 6} to hit, range 100/400 ft., one target. {@h}15 ({@damage 2d10 + 4}) piercing damage. This weapon has the automatic property.

action.name: Rocket Launcher
entries: {@atk rw} {@hit 6} to hit, range 120/480 ft., one target. {@h}11 ({@damage 2d6 + 4}) piercing damage and 7 ({@damage 2d6}) thunder damage. This weapon has the blast property. This weapon must be reloaded with an action after attacking with it.

Why bother arming teens and sending them into war when soldier drones will fight just as well, and without hesitation or mercy. They also won't give you bad PR complaining about things like PTSD or crippling combat wounds. And when they break, you can just toss them in the trash instead of having expensive, boring military funerals.

trait.name: Electronics
entries: Drönaren är känslig för EMP-effekter och liknande effekter.

trait.name: Pack Tactics
entries: The drone has advantage on an attack roll against a creature if at least one of the drone's allies is within 5 ft. of the creature and the ally isn't {@condition incapacitated}.

trait.name: Spider Climb
entries: The drone can climb difficult surfaces, including upside down on ceilings, without needing to make an ability check.

action.name: Metal Maw
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 5} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}7 ({@damage 1d8 + 3}) piercing damage.

action.name: Poisoned Needle
entries: {@atk rw} {@hit 5} to hit, range 60/240 ft., one target. {@h}2 ({@damage 1d4}) piercing damage and the target must succeed on a {@dc 11} Constitution saving throw or take 7 ({@damage 2d6}) poison damage and be {@condition poisoned} for 1 minute.

monster.name: Surgical Drone
languages: understands the languages of its creators

trait.name: Analyze Anatomy
entries: The drone has advantage on any attack rolls against any creature that doesn't have all its hit points.

trait.name: Electronics
entries: Drönaren är känslig för EMP-effekter och liknande effekter.

trait.name: Resuscitate
entries: The drone can spend 1 minute reviving a dead creature within 5 feet of it that died within the last 10 minutes. At the end of this minute, the drone makes a {@dc 20} Wisdom (Medicine) check. On a successful check, the creature returns to life with 1 hit point and its level of {@condition exhaustion} is set to 3.

Den här förmågan kan inte återuppliva en varelse som har dött av ålderdom, och om varelsen saknar kroppsdelar eller organ som är viktiga för dess överlevnad - till exempel huvudet - misslyckas testet automatiskt. Om testet misslyckas för en död varelse kan den här förmågan inte användas på den igen förrän den har återvänt till liv på annat sätt.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The drone makes two attacks: one with its Bonesaw, and one with its Cauterizing brand. It can substitute Surgical Laser for any of these attacks.

action.name: Bonesaw
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 7} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}15 ({@damage 2d10 + 4}) slashing damage. On a critical hit against a creature, the attack severs a limb of the drone's choice from the target.

action.name: Cauterizing Brand
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 7} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}13 ({@damage 2d8 + 4}) fire damage, and the target begins begins burning for 1 minute, taking 3 ({@damage 1d6}) fire damage at the beginning of each of its turns.

action.name: Surgical Laser
entries: {@atk rw} {@hit 7} to hit, range 50/200 ft., one target. {@h}13 ({@damage 2d8 + 4}) radiant damage.

Surgical drones are life-saving miracle machines. Precise, swift, and geared for most surgical procedures, these drones effectively complement the efforts of surgeons. Given the correct configuration and supplied with plenty of medical supplies, they are also capable of installing most cybernetics, and performing extensive plastic surgery. So long as these helpful medical drones don't turn against civilization, we can put our trust in them when going under their steel blades and pitiless precision.

monster.name: Warrior Drone
languages: understands the languages of its creators

trait.name: Electronics
entries: Drönaren är känslig för EMP-effekter och liknande effekter.

trait.name: Tangling Cables
entries: The drone can attempt to grapple a creature within 5 feet of it as a bonus action without needing a free hand.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The drone makes two weapon attacks.

action.name: Spike Piston
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 5} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}8 ({@damage 1d10 + 3}) piercing damage.

action.name: Shield Slam
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 5} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}7 ({@damage 1d8 + 3}) bludgeoning damage. If the target is a creature, it must succeed on a {@dc 13} Strength saving throw or be knocked {@condition prone}.

action.name: Shot
entries: {@atk rw} {@hit 5} to hit, range 70/280 ft., one target. {@h}7 ({@damage 2d6}) piercing damage.

Warrior drones are frequently kept as local security reinforcements for corporations. Rather than having to pay dozens of security guards to stand around shuffling their feet, you can instead load your security forces into tiny closets, filling nearly every available cubic inch with murderous steel robots. Of course, you can try to do the same with with living guards, but then they start complaining and wanting to start unions. Far cleaner to use drones, whose AI may suffer the dreadful boredom in silence, not being programmed with the ability to complain.

trait.name: Crush
entries: When the tank crashes into another target on its turn, if the target is smaller than the tank, the target takes double damage from the crash.

trait.name: Explosive Death
entries: When the tank is destroyed, it explodes. Targets within 10 feet of the tank must make a {@dc 15} Dexterity saving throw. A target takes 21 ({@dice 6d6}) fire damage on a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful one.

trait.name: Low Center of Gravity

trait.name: Shielded Riders

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The tank makes three ranged attacks - two with its gatling gun and one with its main cannon.

action.name: Gatling Guns
entries: {@atk rw} {@hit 9} to hit, range 100/400 ft., one target. {@h}13 ({@damage 2d10 + 5}) piercing damage. This weapon has the automatic property.

action.name: Main Cannon
entries: {@atk rw} {@hit 9} to hit, range 300/1200 ft., one target. {@h}18 ({@damage 2d12 + 5}) piercing damage and 13 ({@damage 2d12}) thunder damage. This weapon has the blast property.

Battlefield juggernauts, clad in steel, slowly crushing the hopes and dreams of enemy soldiers and loving homes beneath uncaring metal treads. The tank is a staple of any war or 'extended occupation'.

Tanks vary in type, from the lighter tanks to the main battle tanks, or even the more obscure types made possible with advancements in robotic technology. However, in spirit, each tank is very similar. They are a heavy weapons platform with thick armor, crewed by a team of people terrified of leaving their protective metal shell.

entries: Bulletproof windows and armored panels grant total cover to the car's riders from attacks or other effects originating from outside the car. If the windows or doors are opened, this effect is negated on the side they are open.

These vehicles are typically the transport mode of choice for government officials, corporate executives, and other VIPs. The vehicle's cabin and internals, including the undercarriage, are protected by thick armor plating, and the windows are made of tempered bulletproof glass that keeps the occupants safe from harm.

trait.name: Even Keel.

entries: When the boat is destroyed, it explodes. Targets within 10 feet of the boat must make a {@dc 14} Dexterity saving throw. A target takes 21 ({@damage 6d6}) fire damage on a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful one.

The waterways of cities (and the places between cities nobody cares about) are crowded with boats carrying people and goods. Whether it was planned or due to rising waters, some cities are more river than road, making boats the primary means of transportation.

Security forces keep watch over oceans, lakes, canals, and urban water thoroughfares by patrolling on these relatively swift, armed boats.

Public transport is one of many trials and tribulations the average wage slave faces on a daily basis. If you're lucky, the gangsters will leave you alone, and the bus driver is sober enough to drive straight. If you're unlucky... well, at least the stylish graffiti makes it a pretty swag coffin.

trait.name: Explosive Death.
entries: When the car is destroyed, it explodes. Targets within 10 feet of the car must make a {@dc 12} Dexterity saving throw. A target takes 14 ({@damage 4d6}) fire damage on a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful one.

trait.name: Low Center of Gravity.
entries: The car has a +10 bonus to ability checks and saving throws against effects that would knock it {@condition prone}.

The backbone of metropolitan civilization. They range from cheap rust buckets, to premium sports cars for playboys and showoffs, to muscle cars designed for the sole purpose of tearing up tarmac and churning out dust for the suckers behind you to eat.

trait.name: Cinematic Death.
entries: When the car is destroyed, it explodes. Targets within 10 feet of the car must make a {@dc 14} Dexterity saving throw. A target takes 21 ({@damage 6d6}) fire damage on a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful one. However, while the car is racing, it is not destroyed and continues to function even at 0 hit points until someone wins the race, or it suffers a critical hit, or after 10 minutes. The car cannot be repaired while it is at 0 hit points, and it does not grant cover.

trait.name: Burnout Engine (10,000₵ of Turbo Fuel to Recharge over 1 Minute).
entries: As a bonus action, the car's speed doubles until the end of the driver's next turn. For three rounds after the burnout is activated, the car has advantage on Dexterity checks and saving throws. The vehicle can use its reaction to activate the boosters when the vehicle makes a Dexterity saving throw, gaining advantage on the roll. Turbo boosters cannot be installed unless the Burnout Engine is removed.

trait.name: Low Center of Gravity.
entries: The car has a +10 bonus to ability checks and saving throws against effects that would knock it {@condition prone}.

This souped up car was built as an engine first, and a vehicle second. The muscle car seems to have a soul of its own, which shines through in the car's little quirks, even if it isn't technically sentient.

For example, sometimes the horn will honk on its own during times of stress, or if the ejection seating modification is installed, it will malfunction and eject the driver if they are driving too conservatively.

trait.name: Explosive Death.
entries: When the car is destroyed, it explodes. Targets within 10 feet of the car must make a {@dc 13} Dexterity saving throw. A target takes 14 ({@damage 4d6}) fire damage on a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful one.

trait.name: Low Center of Gravity.
entries: The car has a +10 bonus to ability checks and saving throws against effects that would knock it {@condition prone}.

The backbone of metropolitan civilization. They range from cheap rust buckets, to premium sports cars for playboys and showoffs, to muscle cars designed for the sole purpose of tearing up tarmac and churning out dust for the suckers behind you to eat.

trait.name: Evasive Submersion.
entries: While the fortress normally floats buoyantly, it can use its bonus action and half its movement to descend into a liquid until it is 5 feet below the surface. Once submerged, it can't move until it uses another bonus action anbd half its movement to surface.
Aside from this ability, the fortress cannot willingly move beneath the surface of liquids. If forced beneath the surface, the fortress moves toward the surface at a rate of 30 feet per round.

trait.name: Even Keel.
entries: The fortress has a +5 bonus to ability checks and saving throws against effects that would knock it {@condition prone}.

trait.name: Explosive Death.
entries: When the fortress is destroyed, it explodes. Targets within 10 feet of the fortress must make a {@dc 16} Dexterity saving throw. A target takes 28 ({@damage 8d6}) fire damage on a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful one.

trait.name: Shielded Riders.
entries: Bulletproof windows and armored panels grant total cover to the fortress's riders from attacks or other effects originating from outside the fortress. If the windows or doors are opened, this effect is negated on the side they are open.

action.name: Multiattack.
entries: The fortress makes three weapon attacks.

action.name: Rotary Cannon.
entries: {@atk rw} {@hit 10} to hit, range 200/800 ft., one target. {@h}19 ({@damage 2d12 + 6}) piercing damage. This weapon has the automatic property.

action.name: Railgun {@recharge 5}
entries: The fortress fires a magnetically- accelerated projectile in a 1000-foot line that is 5 feet wide. Each creature in that line must make a {@dc 18} Dexterity saving throw, taking 44 ({@damage 8d10}) piercing damage on a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful one.

action.name: Fog Cover (2/Day).
entries: Heating elements boil the liquid around the fortress, creating a 100-foot-radius sphere of fog around it for 1 hour. The sphere spreads around corners, and its area is heavily obscured. A wind of moderate or greater speed (at least 10 miles per hour) disperses it. For 1 minute after this ability is used, creatures submerged in liquid within 10 feet of the fortress take 10 ({@damage 3d6}) fire damage at the start of each of their turns.

Essentially a tank that rides the waves, this slow but unstoppable fortress is equipped with a powerful railgun that launches chunks of metal at speeds that break the sound barrier, as well as multiple deck guns.

It also has special modifications to protect itself during warfare on the open seas. It can seal its ports and hatches closed and submerge itself into water, making it a hard target between its thick armor and the additional defensive barrier of water.
The heating implements on the underside of the fortress can be utilized to boil water near it, creating a thick cloud of fog for evasion or ambushing purposes.

trait.name: Amphibious Aircraft.
entries: The floatplane has a +5 bonus to ability checks and saving throws against effects that would knock it {@condition prone}. While stationary or swimming, the floatplane has a flying speed of 0. To gain its normal flying speed, the floatplane must swim at least 50 feet per round for three rounds in a straight line. While flying, the floatplane must move at least 80 feet in a straight line on its turn or fall.

trait.name: Buoyant.
entries: Designed to float, the fortress cannot willingly move beneath the surface of liquids. If forced beneath the surface, the fortress moves toward the surface at a rate of 30 feet per round.

trait.name: Explosive Death.
entries: When the floatplane is destroyed, it explodes. Targets within 10 feet of the floatplane must make a {@dc 15} Dexterity saving throw. A target takes 28 ({@damage 8d6}) fire damage on a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful one.

The favored aircraft of smugglers, archaeologists, evil millionaires, and anyone who needs to be able to reach remote places far from any airfield. These floatplanes have plenty of range and room for passengers and cargo, and buoyant floats on struts beneath them that allow them to skate along the surface of the water like a boat.

All a floatplane needs for takeoff is any clear section of ocean, lake, or even a reasonably long and straight stretch of river. Hydrobrakes obviate the need for a long landing, but pilots had better beware landing in puddles too small to take off from.

trait.name: Explosive Death.
entries: When the helicopter is destroyed, it explodes. Targets within 10 feet of the helicopter must make a {@dc 16} Dexterity saving throw. A target takes 28 ({@damage 8d6}) fire damage on a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful one.

trait.name: Shielded Riders.
entries: Bulletproof windows and armored panels grant total cover to the helicopter's riders from attacks or other effects originating from outside the helicopter. If the windows or doors are opened, this effect is negated on the side they are open.

trait.name: Stable Flight.
entries: The helicopter has a +5 bonus to ability checks and saving throws against effects that would knock it {@condition prone}.

entries: The helicopter makes four weapon attacks.

action.name: Rotary Cannon.

action.name: Missile Bombardment {@recharge 5}
entries: The helicopter launches a barrage of missiles at a point within 240 feet of it. Each target in a 30-foot-radius sphere centered on that point must make a {@dc 19} Dexterity saving throw, taking 28 ({@dice 8d6}) piercing and 28 ({@damage 8d6}) thunder damage on a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful one.

reaction.name: Decoy Flare.
entries: When the helicopter is attacked by a creature or vehicle it can see that is more than 100 feet away from it, it can impose disadvantage on the attack roll.

The harsh whirring sounds of this enormous helicopter's blades have been the death knell of countless soldiers on the battlefield. Agile, robust, and armed to the teeth with rotary cannons and missiles, they are good reason to fear the open skies.

trait.name: Explosive Death.
entries: When the helicopter is destroyed, it explodes. Targets within 10 feet of the helicopter must make a {@dc 15} Dexterity saving throw. A target takes 21 ({@damage 6d6}) fire damage on a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful one.

trait.name: Shielded Riders.

trait.name: Stable Flight.
entries: The helicopter has a +5 bonus to ability checks and saving throws against effects that would knock it {@condition prone}.

action.name: Multiattack.
entries: The helicopter makes two weapon attacks.

action.name: Gatling Gun.
entries: {@atk rw} {@hit 8} för att träffa, räckvidd 100/400 fot, ett mål. {@h}16 ({@damage 2d10 + 5}) genomträngande skada. Det här vapnet har den automatiska egenskapen.

action.name: Missile Barrage {@recharge 5}
entries: The helicopter launches a barrage of missiles at a point within 240 feet of it. Each target in a 20-foot-radius sphere centered on that point must make a {@dc 16} Dexterity saving throw, taking 17 ({@dice 5d6}) piercing and 17 ({@damage 5d6}) thunder damage on a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful one.

reaction.name: Decoy Flare.
entries: When the helicopter is attacked by a creature or vehicle it can see that is more than 100 feet away from it, it can impose disadvantage on the attack roll.
The assault helicopter's little brother, this well-armed rotorcraft is used by police and corporate security forces everywhere for high-threat situations and aerial pursuit of suspects.

trait.name: Explosive Death.
entries: When the helicopter is destroyed, it explodes. Targets within 10 feet of the helicopter must make a {@dc 13} Dexterity saving throw. A target takes 21 ({@damage 6d6}) fire damage on a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful one.

trait.name: Stable Flight.
entries: The helicopter has a +5 bonus to ability checks and saving throws against effects that would knock it {@condition prone}.

The hypnotic hum of the whirling blades is enough to lull a person to sleep, or wake you up in a cold sweat, depending on your personal experience with rotory-wing aircraft. When space and time are at a premium, it is the helicopter's time to shine. In any city with a thousand high-rises, there are just as many landing pads.

For a high-level executive, the helicopter is crucial for multiple reasons. It allows them to move from meeting to meeting on a precise schedule, the ride itself is smooth and comfortable, and they also afford a good view for looking down on the scum and wage slaves scurrying beneath them, both literally and metaphorically.

Helicopters range in design and purpose from the average news helicopter for carrying passengers, to armed and armored attack helicopters, to enormous airborne predators made to rain death from above, and beyond.

trait.name: Drop-Cable.
entries: The helicopter's swift insertion system for riders to safely reach the ground. A creature riding the helicopter, or near a lowered cable beneath the helicopter, can use its bonus action to tether itself to a cable. The creature can then use half its movement to ascend or descend up to 100 feet without taking falling damage if it lands.

The cable automatically untethers and retracts itself when the creature lands on a solid or liquid surface, or when it re- enters the helicopter. Otherwise the cable allows the creature to hang below the helicopter until the creature lands or it returns to the helicopter.

trait.name: Explosive Death.
entries: When the helicopter is destroyed, it explodes. Targets within 10 feet of the helicopter must make a {@dc 15} Dexterity saving throw. A target takes 28 ({@damage 8d6}) fire damage on a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful one.

trait.name: Shielded Riders.
entries: Bulletproof windows and armored panels grant total cover to the helicopter's riders from attacks or other effects originating from outside the helicopter. If the windows or doors are opened, this effect is negated on the side they are open.

trait.name: Stable Flight.
entries: The helicopter has a +5 bonus to ability checks and saving throws against effects that would knock it {@condition prone}.

action.name: Multiattack.
entries: The helicopter makes three weapon attacks, only one of which can be a Missile attack.

action.name: Rotary Cannon.
entries: {@atk rw} {@hit 9} to hit, range 200/800 ft., one target. {@h}18 ({@damage 2d12 + 5}) piercing damage. This weapon has the automatic property.

action.name: Missile.
entries: {@atk rw} {@hit 9} to hit, range 240/960 ft., one target. {@h}12 ({@damage 2d6 + 5}) piercing damage and 7 ({@damage 2d6}) thunder damage. This weapon has the blast property.

reaction.name: Decoy Flare.
entries: When the helicopter is attacked by a creature or vehicle it can see that is more than 100 feet from it, it can impose disadvantage on the attack roll.

While these transport helicopters are heavily armed and armored, their primary purpose is not to engage in extended skirmishes or battles. Instead, they provide covering fire for the fighting squad they can insert into any combat situation.
In addition to the standard decoy flares to ward off enemy fire, the helicopter comes equipped with drop-cables for swift personnel insertion or extraction.

trait.name: Buoyant.
entries: Designed to float, the jet ski cannot willingly move beneath the surface of liquids. If forced beneath the surface, the jet ski moves toward the surface at a rate of 30 feet per round.

trait.name: Explosive Death.
entries: When the jet ski is destroyed, it explodes. Targets within 10 feet of the jet ski must make a {@dc 11} Dexterity saving throw. A target takes 7 ({@damage 2d6}) fire damage on a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful one.

Speedy and small, these watercraft are designed for a single rider. The sleek and compact design allow for easy navigation down tight canals and waterways, or high speed and maneuverability in more open waters.
They range in quality from the common jet ski, perfect for family vacation fun, to the powerful waverider, which provides high performance for racing or tactical operations in equal measure.

trait.name: Buoyant.
entries: Designed to float, the jet ski cannot willingly move beneath the surface of liquids. If forced beneath the surface, the jet ski moves toward the surface at a rate of 30 feet per round.

They range in quality from the common jet ski, perfect for family vacation fun, to the powerful waverider, which provides high performance for racing or tactical operations in equal measure.

They range in quality from the common jet ski, perfect for family vacation fun, to the powerful waverider, which provides high performance for racing or tactical operations in equal measure.

trait.name: Armored Cockpit.
entries: Bulletproof armor grants total cover to the mech's rider from attacks or other effects originating from outside the suit, while sensors grant the driver vision and audio feed from the outside. If the mech is opened, this effect is negated.

trait.name: Explosive Death.
entries: When the mech is destroyed, it explodes. Targets within 10 feet of the mech must make a {@dc 15} Dexterity saving throw. A target takes 14 ({@damage 4d6}) fire damage on a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful one.

trait.name: Walking Colossus.
entries: If the mech is knocked {@condition prone}, it does not have the flipped condition.

action.name: Multiattack.
entries: The mech makes three weapon attacks.

action.name: Crushing Piston.
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 9} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}18 ({@damage 2d12 + 5}) bludgeoning damage.

action.name: Missile.
entries: {@atk rw} {@hit 9} to hit, range 240/960 ft., one target. {@h}12 ({@damage 2d6 + 5}) piercing damage and 7 ({@damage 2d6}) thunder damage. This weapon has the blast property.

action.name: Railgun {@recharge 4}
entries: The mech fires a magnetically- accelerated projectile in a 800-foot line that is 5 feet wide. Each target in that line must make a {@dc 17} Dexterity saving throw, taking 33 ({@damage 6d10}) piercing damage on a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful one.

action.name: Missile Swarm (1/Day).
entries: The mech unleashes a swarm of missiles in a fan from its back, targeting up to 10 creatures or vehicles it can see within 200 feet of it. The battle mech can make a Missile attack against each target. For 1 minute after using this ability, missiles continue to swirl around the mech, and the mech can use its bonus action on each of its turns to make a single Missile attack.

reaction.name: Deflector Shield.
entries: When the mech is hit by an attack, it can raise a barrier in response, gaining 15 temporary hit points before it takes damage from the triggering attack.

Standing tall on two legs, these machines of war bear a roughly humanoid shape. They stride through battlefield, or rise into the sky on jet propulsion, leaving devastation in their wake. They wield weaponry either built into the mech's frame, or as a person might in the mech's powerful hands.

Mechs are often installed configured with onboard AI to assist with combat coordination and analysis, as it can be difficult for a single rider to control such a complicated piece of advanced technology. In order to be an efficient fighting unit, a mech's AI and its pilot must fight as one. This is often a tricky process, taking numerous battles before a level of trust is reached for a bond to form between machine and pilot.

trait.name: Armored Cockpit.
entries: Bulletproof armor grants total cover to the suit's rider from attacks or other effects originating from outside the suit, while sensors grant the driver vision and audio feed from the outside. If the suit is opened, this effect is negated.

trait.name: Explosive Death.
entries: When the suit is destroyed, it explodes. Targets within 10 feet of the suit must make a {@dc 13} Dexterity saving throw. A target takes 7 ({@damage 2d6}) fire damage on a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful one.

trait.name: Walking Goliath.
entries: If the suit is knocked {@condition prone}, it does not have the flipped condition. The suit has hands that allow the driver to use any melee or ranged weapon the driver is proficient with. When the suit takes the Attack action, it can make the same number of attacks that its driver could if the driver took the Attack action. The suit can also take the Dash action.

The mech suit is a more compact, personal version of the larger mechs. Elite shock troopers prefer them for battles in close quarters, such as moving room to room in an urban conflict. They allow the user to utilize their normal weapons, receiving recoil and impact feedback from the haptic technology built into the gauntlets.

trait.name: Armored Cockpit.
entries: Bulletproof armor grants total cover to the mech's riders from attacks or other effects originating from outside the suit, while sensors grant the driver vision and audio feed from the outside. If the mech is opened, this effect is negated.

trait.name: Epic Death.
entries: When the mech is destroyed, it explodes in a fantastic burst of light that can be seen from 100 miles away. Targets within 100 feet of the mech must make a {@dc 24} Constitution saving throw. A target takes 33 ({@damage 6d10}) radiant damage on a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful one.

trait.name: Legendary Resistance (3/Day).
entries: If the mech fails a saving throw, it can choose to succeed instead.

trait.name: Pulsar Engine.
entries: While the mech is below half its hit points, its speed doubles, it gains an additional legendary action, and when it rolls a {@dice d6} to recharge one of its actions, it automatically recharges the action. Additionally, while this ability is active, at the start of the mech's turn, creatures within 200 feet of the mech must succeed on a {@dc 15} Constitution saving throw or gain 1 level of irradiated.

trait.name: Walking Titan.
entries: If the mech is knocked {@condition prone}, it does not have the flipped condition.

action.name: Multiattack.
entries: The mech makes two melee weapon attacks.

action.name: Ion Blade.
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 17} to hit, reach 20 ft., one target. {@h}27 ({@damage 4d8 + 9}) slashing damage and 16 ({@damage 3d10}) force damage.

action.name: Missile.
entries: {@atk rw} {@hit 16} to hit, range 240/960 ft., one target. {@h}15 ({@damage 2d6 + 8}) piercing damage and 7 ({@damage 2d6}) thunder damage. This weapon has the blast property.

action.name: Warp Strike {@recharge 5}
entries: The mech can make an ion blade attack against up to 4 targets it can see within 100 feet of it. It then teleports to an unoccupied space it can see within 20 feet of one of the targets.

action.name: Neutron Cannon {@recharge 5}
entries: The mech fires a beam of energy in a line that is 10 miles long and 15 feet wide. Each creature in that line must make a {@dc 24} Dexterity saving throw, taking 66 ({@damage 12d10}) force damage damage on a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful one.

reaction.name: Warp Barrier.
entries: When the mech is hit by a ranged weapon attack, the mech is unaffected, and the effect is reflected back at the attacker as though it originated from the mech, turning the attacker into the target.

legendary.name: Scan.
entries: One of the mech's drivers makes a Wisdom (Perception) check with advantage.

legendary.name: Missile Attack.
entries: The mech makes a missile attack.

legendary.name: Ion Blade Attack (Costs 2 Actions).
entries: The mech makes an ion blade attack.

legendary.name: Jet Boosters (Costs 2 Actions).
entries: The mech activates its jets and superheats the air around it. Each target within 10 feet of the mech must succeed on a {@dc 24} Dexterity saving throw or take 13 ({@damage 2d6 + 8}) fire damage. The vehicle can then fly up to half its flying speed.

legendary.name: Armageddon Countdown (Costs 3 Actions, 1/Day)
entries: The mythical mech begins charging up its pulsar engine. At the end of each round, for 3 rounds, an effect occurs. On initiative count 0 for the first two rounds, creatures within 200 feet of the mech that can see it must make a {@dc 24} Constitution saving throw, taking 14 ({@damage 4d6}) radiant damage on a failed save, or half as much on a successful save.

On initiative count 0 of the third round, the mythical mech gains the ability to cast the nuke spell once (spell save {@dc 24}) without spellcasting components, and with a casting time of 1 action. The mech must cast the spell within 10 minutes.
"What's that? The transponder signature of that mech... could it really be...?"
"Impossible! They're just a myth, a fairy tale! Move in and destroy it!"
"Eeeaarrgh!" Explosions, then the signal goes dead.

This mech must just be a legend. Its weapon systems are too advanced, its defenses too impenetrable, and its engine too powerful for it be real. Such would have to be the result of intermingling magical artifacts and state-of-the-art technology beyond our current means.

But, hypothetically, if it were real, it would be a demon on any battlefield, capable of demolishing an army by itself. The scale of destruction it could cause would make it on par with a weapon of mass destruction.

Such a demon could not be controlled by one pilot; the strain of managing the mech's combat capabilities and battle data would overwhelm any single person. Instead, it would need to be piloted by a team of two individuals who had built a level of synchronicity allowing them to operate in tandem as a single force of will guiding the mech.
Like I said before, just a legend.

trait.name: Armored Cockpit.
entries: Bulletproof armor grants total cover to the mech's rider from attacks or other effects originating from outside the suit, while sensors grant the driver vision and audio feed from the outside. If the mech is opened, this effect is negated.

trait.name: Explosive Death.
entries: When the mech is destroyed, it explodes. Targets within 10 feet of the mech must make a {@dc 15} Dexterity saving throw. A target takes 21 ({@damage 6d6}) fire damage on a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful one.

trait.name: Legendary Resistance (2/Day).
entries: If the mech fails a saving throw, it can choose to succeed instead.

trait.name: Walking Behemoth.
entries: If the mech is knocked {@condition prone}, it does not have the flipped condition.

action.name: Multiattack.
entries: The mech makes two weapon attacks.

action.name: Heated Blade.
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 11} to hit, reach 10 ft., one target. {@h}21 ({@damage 3d10 + 5}) slashing damage and the target begins burning for 1 minute so long as it is not already burning from a heated blade attack, taking 13 ({@damage 3d8}) fire damage at the start of each of its turns.

action.name: Missile.
entries: {@atk rw} {@hit 11} to hit, range 240/960 ft., one target. {@h}12 ({@damage 2d6 + 5}) piercing damage and 7 ({@damage 2d6}) thunder damage. This weapon has the blast property.

action.name: Gauss Cannon {@recharge 5}
entries: The mech fires a beam of concentrated energy in a 2,000-foot line that is 10 feet wide. Each creature in that line must make a {@dc 19} Dexterity saving throw, taking 49 ({@damage 9d10}) force damage damage on a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful one.

action.name: Missile Swarm (1/Day).
entries: The mech unleashes a swarm of missiles in a fan from its back, targeting up to 10 creatures or vehicles it can see within 200 feet of it. The battle mech can make a rocket launcher attack against each target. For 1 minute after using this ability, missiles continue to swirl around the mech, and the mech can use its bonus action on each of its turns to make a single rocket launcher attack.

reaction.name: Deflector Shield.
entries: When the mech is hit by an attack, it can raise a barrier in response, gaining 20 temporary hit points before it takes damage from the triggering attack.

legendary.name: Scan.
entries: The mech's driver makes a Wisdom (Perception) check.

legendary.name: Missile Attack.
entries: The mech makes a missile attack.

legendary.name: Heated Blade Attack (Costs 2 Actions).
entries: The mech makes a heated blade attack.

legendary.name: Jet Boosters (Costs 2 Actions).
entries: The mech activates its jets and superheats the air around it. Each target within 10 feet of the mech must succeed on a {@dc 19} Dexterity saving throw or take 13 ({@damage 2d6 + 5}) fire damage. The vehicle can then fly up to half its flying speed.

Standing tall on two legs, these machines of war bear a roughly humanoid shape. They stride through battlefield, or rise into the sky on jet propulsion, leaving devastation in their wake. They wield weaponry either built into the mech's frame, or as a person might in the mech's powerful hands.

Mechs are often installed configured with onboard AI to assist with combat coordination and analysis, as it can be difficult for a single rider to control such a complicated piece of advanced technology. In order to be an efficient fighting unit, a mech's AI and its pilot must fight as one. This is often a tricky process, taking numerous battles before a level of trust is reached for a bond to form between machine and pilot.

trait.name: Explosive Death.
entries: When the humvee is destroyed, it explodes. Targets within 10 feet of the humvee must make a {@dc 15} Dexterity saving throw. A target takes 14 ({@damage 4d6}) fire damage on a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful one.

trait.name: Low Center of Gravity.
entries: The humvee has a +10 bonus to ability checks and saving throws against effects that would knock it {@condition prone}.

trait.name: Shielded Riders.
entries: Bulletproof windows and armored panels grant total cover to the humvee's riders from attacks or other effects originating from outside the humvee. If the windows or doors are opened, this effect is negated on the side they are open.

action.name: Multiattack.
entries: The carrier makes two weapon attacks.

action.name: Gatling Gun.
entries: {@atk rw} {@hit 8} to hit, range 100/400 ft., one target. {@h}11 ({@damage 2d10}) piercing damage. This weapon has the automatic property.

These vehicles are your standard issue ground transport vehicles for patrol or insertion into dangerous situations. Thick armor protects soldiers inside from direct weapons fire, while mounted weapons provide covering fire for those making a break into nearby terrain or buildings.

Of course, they cost a small fortune to buy and arm, of which a non-insignificant portion goes to kickbacks and bribes for the politicians that authorized the expenditure. Unfortunately, that cuts a bit into the armor budget, as do the bonuses for the manufacturer's CEO, but leaving it a bit on the thin and brittle side probably won't make a difference.
After all, it's what the soldiers signed up for, right?

trait.name: Explosive Death.
entries: When the carrier is destroyed, it explodes. Targets within 10 feet of the carrier must make a {@dc 15} Dexterity saving throw. A target takes 21 ({@damage 6d6}) fire damage on a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful one.

trait.name: Low Center of Gravity.
entries: The carrier has a +10 bonus to ability checks and saving throws against effects that would knock it {@condition prone}.

trait.name: Shielded Riders.
entries: Bulletproof windows and armored panels grant total cover to the carrier's riders from attacks or other effects originating from outside the carrier. If the windows or doors are opened, this effect is negated on the side they are open.

action.name: Multiattack.
entries: The carrier makes two weapon attacks.

action.name: Assault Cannon.
entries: {@atk rw} {@hit 8} to hit, range 120/480 ft., one target. {@h}18 ({@damage 2d12 + 5}) piercing damage.

action.name: Rocket Launcher.
entries: {@atk rw} {@hit 8} to hit, range 120/480 ft., one target. {@h}12 ({@damage 2d6 + 5}) piercing damage and 7 ({@damage 2d6}) thunder damage. This weapon has the blast property.

The military transport vehicle is capable of bringing a squad of armed soldiers to the battlefront. Equipped with the lovely pair of an assault cannon and a rocket launcher, it's more than capable of warding off insurgent forces en route. Overly zealous police or corporate security forces will also sometimes utilize these carriers.

While not exactly built for comfort, the interior is spacey enough for a small armory of firearms, body armor, and ordinance. Or, if you're optimistic, perhaps food, tents, and other supplies for a humanitarian mission. Just don't expect a pleasant smell, the carrier does not come equipped with a shower.

trait.name: Explosive Death.
entries: When the motorcycle is destroyed, it explodes. Targets within 10 feet of the motorcycle must make a {@dc 11} Dexterity saving throw. A target takes 7 ({@damage 2d6}) fire damage on a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful one.

The motorcycle gang moves like a pack of wolves along neon- stained streets, weaving in between cars and trailer trucks, the gangsters hooting and hollering all the way. The motorcycle is an iconic part of the cyberpunk genre.

They're also dangerous for the inexperienced and untrained rider. Capable of extremely high speeds, but lacking the stability of a four-wheel vehicle, all it takes is one slip for a catastrophe to occur. Of course, when you're high as a rocket ship and don't know any better, that sort of thing doesn't really cross your mind.

Motorcycles range in quality of build from cheap, unbalanced deathtraps, to professional and motocross grade deathtraps, all the way to highly engineered, full-throttle deathtraps. Just do you and your family a favor and get some life insurance before you hop on one of these bad boys.

trait.name: Explosive Death.
entries: When the motorcycle is destroyed, it explodes. Targets within 10 feet of the motorcycle must make a {@dc 11} Dexterity saving throw. A target takes 7 ({@damage 2d6}) fire damage on a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful one.
